posts.author: Thazzle
posts.content:
Story
For many years she was the finest soldier Cormyr had ever seen. She wielded her swords with grace and skill, and many foes fell before her without even getting to swing their blades. Being a soldier, however, was not what she wanted to be. She wanted to hunt down evil and to protect the innocent wherever, whenever - so one day when she came upon a cleric of Tyr, she decided to go with him. She studied the the ways of The Just God and began to believe that it was no coincidence, that she had met the cleric. She joined the church and began her quest for ridding the world of evil. After many years of tirelessly killing evil wherever it rose, she began to see the futilty of her efforts. Evil was everywhere and would always return. She decided that she would turn her efforts away from lesser evils and focus on the greater ones. She sought out the Harpers, who she had heard would fit her needs, and offered to join them. The Harpers took her in and she quickly rose in the ranks.
As an incredible fighter and a holy warrior she is like a machine, cutting down evil creatures swiftly and easily and without mercy.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey man!

Nice to see you're already getting busy in your first days here. Now, as for the build, IMO it could use some tweaks. I don't have enough time to look at it in-depth, but I see some problems with it:

1- Cat's Grace and Eagle's Splendor don't stack with themselves, so you cannot attain the bonus twice. They stack with other spells that give bonus to the same ability (Aura of Glory, for example).

2- Your AB is kind of low, given your focus in CHARISMA, which is like the worst possible scenario for a dual-wielder. I would consider investing less in charisma and more in DEX. Here is the reasoning: a DEX-based pally will always have the DEX bonus to AC and AB thanks to Weapon Finesse, while the CHA bonus to AC from Divine Shield will only be on for a limited period of time. By investing in DEX instead of CHA, you lose Divine Might damage and duration and Divine Shield duration, but you gain a permanent increase to AC and especially AB.

3- You could go with more Paladin pre-epic and use the Fighter Bonus Feats to take feats in epics, not to mention your buffs will be stronger much sooner, which is desirable. Paladin 15 Fighter 5 before 20 is the best.

4- You could change the spread to Paladin 23 Fighter 12 HS 5 and keep the same number of feats while adding duration to your buffs and making it less likely to be dispelled.

Gotta go to work, I'll continue my analysis later on.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Thazzle, great to see you posting already and thanks so much also for the story (a paladin build is always a welcome sight to my eyes, and especially a paladin build with a story--Good Stuff!). OK, see the dilemma here, and agree with Max re: the need to get more DEX which although CHA is quite cool, you're not a Smiter here so no need for so much CHA (even though, yes, makes the Harper Champion good looking.

The Divines are nice, but don't last all that long so as to make more DEX worth it, I agree. With your buffs and potion making abilities, can get a nice boost from the Divines at 16 or so CHA, putting the rest into DEX for your AB and AC (which unlike the Divines, don't run out and/or need to be re-charged, but stay with you, I agree).

I LOVE the Paladin, and Max has some rather nice suggestions there for you, to which I'll add: Take it to 25 Paladin, 5 Harper with the rest into FTR. At 5 off from 25 Pally, that's like having a pot of gold in front of you, reaching long and hard for it and finally getting there only to decide not to reach out for it. Unless something has totally changed in the 1.69 patch (see the Pally FINALLY got its Warhorse, heh, heh), 25 caster levels (i.e. 25 levels of Paladin) means your Paladin buffs cannot be dispelled. (This changed in NWN2, don't know why all of a sudden Paladins were treated differently, but in NWN2 paladin caster is only equal to half of your total Paladin level, meaning a NWN2 Paladin can NEVER get to be a non-dispellable caster (which is just plain awful); this, unlike in NWN (or PnP/D&D),where Paladins remain, well, real Paladins. Namely, caster level equals your Paladin level and, so long as you get to 25-plus levels of Paladin, your buffs are solid--aka non-dispellable in turn). 25 Caster levels = the Pot of Gold!

I like Max' suggestions for you, but with caster levels in mind, just a couple more suggestions in turn (i.e., with solid, non-dispellable buffs, means they can be counted on). Thus, no problem losing 2 FTR (I do like EWS shortsword, and impr.crit, seeing Armor Skin as the potential Candidate to drop. Assuming non-dispel/25 Paladin, the Champion will be fine--lots of great buffs, not to mention lots of damage options as well (there are some really good ones!). In terms of HPs, can get away with 400-ish (Max, put Toughness back in! 380 is too low). I would also think about dropping EITHER Divine Might or Divine Shield for i.e. Toughness, since both draw from the same pool. Ordinarily, I like Might; however, if bring your Naked, Unbuffed AB to 44 as is suggested above, bolstered by (at 25 Paladin) NON-DISPELLABLE Paladin buffs, then I'd be inclined to keep the DS but not DM (a nice AC boost when required, the Pally book having nice buffs/damage but not so much in the way of AC). (Note: 400HPs is about the minimum for anything that melees, so work Toughness back in there ... especially since with all that DEx and no uncanny dodge ...

I don't disagree with Max when it comes to taking pre-epic feats in epic, though I prefer to get all my pre-epics before hitting the epic portion of my career, sometimes it just can't be helped. All that matters in the end is that you get to where it is that you are going, and have a ton of fun with it of course along the way. Some really nice suggestions there for you, and just a few thoughts that come to my mind as well.

And to Ye Harper Champion I say, stay true to all that is just and good, and good and just ye shall always be!

~ Tyr

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Tyr, I don't know if that's a post 1.69 thing, but to be effectively undispellable, you need 24 CLs, not 25. There was a thread in the old ECB about that. Now as to your suggestion, I wouldn't advise dropping a feat, but if you must, go Paladin 29 HS 5 Ftr 6. You lose 3 Feats and gain 2, leaving you with even more caster levels and the same number of feats than your 25 Pally alternative. However I would advise you not to do that because the best paladin buffs are short-term, so 5% dispellability isn't much of a problem, especially for a non-UMDer with a mild feat starvation. IMO the best spread for this class combo is 23-12-5, and the second best is 29-6-5.

Anyway, Thazzle, it's common for elder builders to disagree, because of playstyle differences. You have to take these suggestions and analize which one of them fits your playstyle better.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
My thoughts on going charisma based.
You get glorious saves and a very high temporary bonus to AC and divine damage. The higher the charisma, the better your divine feats will be.
The downside is, like Max pointed out that your AB will suffer if you go overboard with charisma and forget strength, or as in this case dexterity.
A sound fighter type build should normaly have a naked AB in the 40s. +44 is a good benchmark.
Builds that can self buff can get away with less. Paladins have that option with bless/aid/prayer/divine favor that can add +8 to AB for a limited period. GMW and holy sword will also add to AB, but will not help much once +5 weapons are available. Normally a paladin can self buff strength and charisma. If you focus on dexterity, your harper scout can provide some dexterity buff, but i guess it will be of limited duration with only 5 levels in harper scout (correct me if I'm wrong.)
Paladins also have the taunt skill that will help reduce the AC of your opponent.
Buffing up for every fight, activating the divine feats and taunting your enemy, takes some time. It makes the character more complicated to play, and the time you spend preparing for every fight has a negative impact on the overall effectiveness of your character. But then again your reward is better armor, a fair damage output and a certain "coolness" factor.
I believe that a paladin with all available buffs should at least have a naked AB in the upper 30s, rather close to +40 (like Tyr recomends). A strength (or dexterity) of 20 along with full BAB progression and the AB enhancing feats should get you there, leaving plenty of room to build up adequate charisma.

My thoughts on dual wielding.
Divine shield gives enough AC to let you drop the shield.
Dual wield inflicts a -2 AB penalty, so you should be careful since you don't have a high AB in the first place.
Strength based damage bonus is cut in half on the off hand weapon. Charisma based divine damage from divine might is not reduced.
Effective TWF forces you to take at least 15 dexterity.

My thoughts on a dexterity build.
I like strength better than dexterity in this kind of builds.
You will need dex 26 in a paded armor to get an AC equal to a full plate. Maybe you can get there with buffs from harper scout. The alternative is leather armor (and dex 22) or a chainshirt (and dex 18), but the AC will be slightly lower.
Dex based AC is at best risky when you do not have the uncanny dodge feat.
You will not be able to qualify for epic dex based feats.
You do not take any dex based skills except tumble.
Strength improves the damage output.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Mick, I would like to offer a different angle on what you said.

In the alternative I offered, his naked AB is 44. He has Bless, Aid, Prayer, GMW and Divine Favor, and depending on magic level, he can cap both CHA and DEX (he can craft Harper Items), even if for a short time. that's +13 to Magical AB enhancement, with +6 from dex. This means 63 AB (61 DWing) and not factoring in a successful Taunt. With that kind of AB he shouldn't have any problem hitting. Now, with 7 APR (assuming Haste) and several damage bonuses (+5 GMW, +5 Divine Favor, +9 Divine Might, +1 Prayer, +1 or +2 STR, and maybe +3 Deafening Clang), he will have an excellent damage output and make the best use of the short-term damage buffs he has, which are many.

ANY PALADIN (Except my Ugly Mug Hero, who is more of a Fighter with many Paladin levels) is to me a mediocre character who has a few moments of godliness (real godliness). If he knows how to conserve his most important buffs for the most important battles, he will do well. CHA-based smiters, even my Holy WM with cheese are in the same area. They have average stats that are VERY BUFFABLE for a short time, which is generally enough to win any single battle. The STR-based alternative is cool too, no doubt, but then it makes less and less sense to take some Paladin specific features, like DM and DS. I like the synergies he explores here, so I'd say that you're selling this build a bit short when you say this. True, he doesn't get ED or SC, but there are some pretty nice things this build can do. Damage output shouldn't be an issue, in fact his DW will probably make him do more damage than the average STR-based Paladin just due to the extra attacks while fully buffed against most enemy types.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Paladin a mediocre character? YIKES!!! So not true! (well, mine aren't, never have been, and I don't mean my Lionheart Ranger/WM or WM/Paladins or Wing Commander, my dev.criting Pal26/RDD10 either), but my GS VIII Paladin (with a Naked AB 40, +7Smite / Self-Buff 60,+12 Smite: 72, or for -1 ab gets GS X! Mick and I together worked on that GS smiter (please don't get me started on NWN2 ... LOL). Nope. Nothing average about the Paladin, or the fear/mind immunities and saves that are out of this world; nothing mediocre about it at all!!

Holy Sword lest we forget also carries the on-hit dispel magic prop, so has its uses ... This, in addition to Paladin Dispel (part of the good book) so as to remove buffs off enemies, hence more AB etc. likewise in turn (assuming there's something to dispel). Thing about going Dex based though, no discipline and all of its lost when caught flat-footed or prone. (I explored the Dex angle with SC-5 and ED, much better for high magic worlds, as is the case of ALL DEXERS, need equipment to do any damage, as damage comes not from DEX but STR. That said, the Pally book does help, this is true; yes, DM offers a nice bonus but takes time to turn on both DM and DS (which are great with high cha, whole thing about the divines and buffs being about the Smiting: incredible damage, enemy is dead. Dont' need the divines in turn to last at all long. A smite does the trick, often is the case you only need just the one (multiplies all of it on a crit., too). Then, thing about most dexers is they are sneak charged and rely on the stealth to deliver that damage, much the same way most Paladins rely on the Smite. Then, there's the balanced approach (all depends, if good v evil go smite and lots of it; otherwise, balancing makes sense, always did).

But regardless, no damage--whether sneak, smite, physical or otherwise--delivers itself. For that, need AB but also need to stand on one's feet to deliver it (dex without uncanny goes out the window AC wise, and dodge, tumble is also lost). Need a good AC to avoid being hit in the first place, and why DS (with the Dex) when REALLY need it works here, but to make DM and DS work would require (I believe) too much focus on CHA, taking away from Dex and other things a build (not Smite, not Sneak, not STR-damage based) like this needs.

In terms of Paladin buffs, assuming a 22 DEX (BAB 30, AB 40- with wf/ewf and EP), you're looking at 63 self-buffed
(+3 aid, prayer, bless, +5 GMW (or Holy Sword, which also adds Divine damage v evil), +5 Divine Favor), add CHA modifier for a Smite Evil boni once per day. In terms of damage, though, Bull's helps, as will the +5 Divine Favor (magic), with 1d6 divine vs Evil (Holy Sword), with Bless weapon (2d6 divine) for undeads. So, no, not hopeless, but not the same as STR based (that doesn't depend on buffs). Suppose if she's playing in a higher magic world he'll be able to enhance magical weapons, but is the AB sufficient to hit when against high magic critters? That's actually when she'll enjoy her Holy Sword On-Hit: Dispel Magic the most. That said, all dexers are dependent on gear and lots of it to deliver any damage (with the exception of sneak-charged rogue/assassins, then, they also sneak reliant, attack through stealth, and a totally different beast; but as against the crit immune like undeads, heh, give me epic Paladin turning over that anyday ... heh, heh). FTR WS/EWS definitely also helps, if goes that route and which I highly recommend, too: gives 6 damage (which isn't buff dependent. An AB 40- (plus the buffs) to deliver, leaving enough for CHA charged DS (without Uncanny, I likewise worry when it comes to DEX based builds. Not an archer in the shadows, but a melee build. All that Dex out the window ....

But no, definitely NOT hopeless. and no body's saying that. What Mick's saying (and I happen to agree) is that'd be better if goes STR, as pooling off the same stat. for AB/Damage, as opposed to requiring STR (Dam), DEX (AG, AC w.o Uncanny), CHA (for divines) AND Wis for the spells on top of all of that, too. What I'm saying: So long as has a decent AB (40+) AND decent HPs (400 are minimum on a melee, ... WM crits do about 100 (or more) damage per crit, with 4 apr (and of course if haste is available, they get that, too). For PvM/E, though? Still 400. There be some really tough undeads out there (not all zombies are push-overs, and lots of things like to IKD). Thing is, saves are really nice, and has the Good Pally book, too. Trying to squeeze a lot in here, though.

Pulling a lot of stats--and that in turn thins things/results in equipment dependency. To put it another way, the more one tries to do, the more one needs more gear to do it. No way of sugar coating that ...

Thazzle: I am being quite gentle when I say that (those here who've long known me will tell you (I hope, or I'll SMITE 'em, heh heh) that I'm a nice person, but at the same time, I HATE it when people rely on gear. Really, who says you're going to get all that gear and as if not more importantly, even if you do, then everything you're up against has all that same great gear, too. (Had to be said, just did, otherwise some may begin to wonder if it's really me Tyr posting here. But I really am trying to be gentle, then, I liked your story. Appreciate that yoyu're trying to do something different, but watering down your stats unecessarily in turn. Might want to have a look int he build search engine under builder name, Mithdradates who put together a Pal/HS/FTR for PvM--1-40; goes STR of it, to Naked AB 42 (Pal buff for more), and a really nice story that goes with it, too. http://home.comcast.net/~worldofgreyhaw ... 42563.html .

Cheers

EDIT: did I mention that I Love Paladins? Rather quite like that --FINALLY--they can summon their War Mount, too.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Tyr, on a side note, I have to tell you that Holy Sword has been nerfed, more specifically the DISPEL property you're talking about. The way it is now, it pretty much doesn't dispel anything anymore. I don't know the exact specifications of this, just the consequence.

As for Paladins, well, I like them as much as you do, and I have to tell you that I can't see how an AB of 40 can reach 63 with PAL buffs only, unless you're talking about smites, which only further enhances my point of view. What I mean is this: a fully-buffed AB of 63 can help in certain situations, but will a fully buffed AB be there for you in all battles? The answer is no. I'll take my pally WM as an example: She has a fully-buffed AB of 64, which is awesome! as well as a fully-buffed AC of 78, which is even more awesome! Now, with that said, she can't keep those buffs up long enough for more than one HARD battle a day. Most of the time, she walks around at 63 AC and 57 AB, which is average, not helpless. Now, it all boils down to where you play, but this toon built by Thazzle has some cool synergies. He just needs to invest on Listen or Spot, to make sure he sees his enemy coming. The loss of DEX to AC can be a pain, I have just mentioned my Magical Master toon on another topic, which is a DEX-based Cleric / Monk / Wizard with no Uncanny Dodge. True, he doesn't really need UD, cuz of all the nifty magicks he can pull, but nonetheless it's a pain, not a buildbreaker nor reason to go STR-based IMO.
